Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Engineering Three-dimensional Stem Cell Niche with Independently Tunable Biochemical and Mechanical Properties

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1351289
Yang

The overall goal of this project is to develop a novel stem cell niche with biochemical and mechanical properties, which can be tuned independently; and to use this niche to elucidate how signals influence stem cell fate in three dimensions using high-throughput strategies.

Intellectual merit
Stem cells have the potential to revolutionize medical therapies for a number of diseases. However, directing stem cell fate so that they maintain pluripotency or mutlipotency, or they commit to a certain differentiation lineage, is a critical problem in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine. Although there is ample evidence that stem cells respond to both biochemical and mechanical cues, understanding how the totality of signals in a given environment directs cell fate remains a largely unanswered question, especially in three dimensions (3D). Recent studies from the PI's laboratory indicate that biochemical and mechanical cues interact in a non-intuitive manner to regulate stem cell fate, which cannot be predicted from stem cell responses to individual type of niche cues. The proposed studies are designed to advance the understanding of stem cell-niche interactions by pursuing the following research objectives:
Objective 1. Synthesize degradable polymers as biochemical and mechanical "building blocks" of stem cell niche that can crosslink simultaneously and independently to form an interpenetrating network.
Objective 2. Develop biomimetic hydrogel microarrays with independently tunable niche
properties for encapsulating cells in 3D.
Objective 3. Examine the effects of interactive niche signaling on stem cell differentiation in 3D combinatorial hydrogel microarrays in a high-throughput manner.
The systematic and combined approach implemented by the PI has a high intellectual merit. Additionally, the proposed studies carry multiple innovative features including the development of interpenetrating network hydrogels with independent control of biochemical and mechanical cues; AFM and FRET-based assays for high-throughput characterization of hydrogel stiffness and degradation; and novel microfabrication platforms and high-throughput screening assays for rapid monitoring of stem cell fate in 3D.

Broader Impacts
The proposed development of biomimetic hydrogel microarrays with independently tunable cues is expected to comprise a powerful tool to advance the fundamental understanding of stem cell-niche interactions in 3D, thus addressing a critical problem in stem cell biology and tissue engineering. The outcomes of the proposed research may greatly accelerate stem cell-based therapies by rapidly identifying optimal cues to direct stem cells into maintaining pluripotency or differentiating into functional mature cells. Ongoing and new educational plans target students from kindergarten to undergraduates. An outreach program for local elementary school K-G1 students, called "The Magic of Repairing Human Body," will be developed. The PI will also develop a one-week summer camp for high school students on "Tissue Engineering Fiesta, which will include interactive lectures, journal clubs and hands-on activities and will be geared towards high school students from underprivileged and minority background in the San Francisco Bay Area. Overall, the PI addresses a challenging problem with broader implications and has demonstrated commitment towards educational and outreach activities with local schools with diverse student populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While stem cell niche is a multi-factorial environment, previous studies are largely restricted to studying the effects of individual type of microenvironmental cue on stem cell fate regulation. Furthermore, few biomaterials developed to-date allow decoupling of niche properties such as biochemical signals and mechanical stiffness. The goal of this CAREER proposal was to develop a novel stem cell niche with independently tunable biochemical and mechanical properties to elucidate how complex interplay of niche signals influence stem cell fate in 3D using high-throughput strategies.

Throughout the award period, our team has successfully developed multiple 3D hydrogels as stem cell niche that specifically address the limitations of previous biomaterials, including combinatorial 3D hydrogel arrays, hydrogels with interpenetrating network, and gradient hydrogels with continuous changes in niche cues such as matrix stiffness or biochemical ligand density. Using these hydrogel tools, we demonstrate how complex niche signaling impact stem cell differentiation towards multiple lineages such as cartilage or bone. Importantly, these  hydrogel tools enable rapid and real-time monitoring of stem cells fate in 3D using minimal amount of materials, cells and time. We also disseminate the knowledge gained from these studies through presentations at various national conferences as well as journal publications.

Upon completion of this proposal, we have developed novel biomaterials tools to advance fundamental understanding of stem cell-niche interactions in 3D, which represents a key bottleneck in stem cell biology and tissue engineering. The findings of the research will greatly accelerate stem cell-based therapy by rapidly identifying optimal niche cues to direct stem cells into functional mature cells. Importantly, these novel hydrogels tools are versatile and can be easily adapted to examine cell-niche interactions in 3D of any stem cells including pluripotent or multipotent stem cells, and cancer stem cells.  

The broader impacts of this proposal are also achieved by new educational plans that target students from kindergarten, high school students to undergraduates and graduate students. It also offered valuable research training opportunities for multiple graduate and undergraduate students to gain first-hand research experience working on interdisciplinary projects that lie at the interface of engineering, materials science, biology and medicine. A key element of our education efforts also includes developing outreach programs to foster interest in science to younger students by offering short outreach programs targeting a broad range of age students ranging from elementary school students to high school students. It also offered summer research opportunities for high school students from underprivileged and minority background in the San Francisco Bay Area.  

 


Last Modified: 05/04/2020
Modified by: Fan Yang
